remixed_from.author: QuadFramesUK
remixed_from.title: EZ Antenna Tracker / Ground Station, EZtracker Immersion RC

description.text:
My case design for the excellent Ghettostation Antenna Tracker from KipK.
The case was inspired by the EZ Antenna Tracker / Ground Station, EZtracker Immersion RC by RcHobbysUK here on Thingiverse.
The case features:

• 0-135 degree Tilt Head
  • 360 degree Pan mount (ball bearing supported)
  • Antenna quick change/release to allow use of multiple different antennas
  • ImmersionRC Duo 5800 V3, V4, Uno5800 V2 and Uno2400 Video RX mount (single mini DIN connection, lever for frequency selection)
  • Lawmate 2.4Ghz mount
  • 3DR Radio Telemetry Module (900Mhz or 433 Mhz) mount on the tracking plate
  • Easy access Battery compartment for up to 3700mAh 4S LiPo Pack
  • LCD mount and holes for the 3 selection buttons
  • Arduino Mega 2560 Rev 3 Mounting tabs including USB connector cut out
  • Mounts for Battery Voltage Alarm, Power On/Off, Ground OSD Power On/Off, 4x Video out, 1x T-Style/Deans Power connector
  • Tripod Quickmount and additional feet for table top/car roof top positioning
    Please refer to the instructions for details on the used components and links to the Software and Forum.
    • Updates: 21/11/2014:
  • updated rear case with more servo clearance to accommodate taller servos such as the GWS S125-1T/2BB Winch Servo and nut slots added for reach cover mount (the plastic wears out quite quickly if the case is opened and closed multiple times. Adding a nut solves this).
  • Servo spacer for GWS S125 added
    • 31/12/2014:
  • ImmersionRC Duo5800 mount renamed to DUO5800_V3 in preparation for release of a mount suitable for the DUO5800 V4
    • 4/1/2014:
  • Happy 2015 everyone. Mounting plate for DUO5800 V4 added. You will need to print 2 of the Duo5800_push.stl and Duo5800_lever.stl for the V4 of the DUO5800 as it has both Band and Frequency selection buttons. As I'm not the proud owner of a V4 and the design is based on drawings received from ImmersionRC, please do let me know in case changes are required once you tested it out (and also drop a note in case it works fine as is). Thanks
    • 27/1/2015: Turnplate updated to allow removal of the top without the need to pull the cables through before.
    29/1/2015:
    Added RX mounts for ImmersionRC Uno5800 V2 and Uno2400 (same mount as Uno5800) receiver and Lawmate 2.4Ghz receiver 16/2/2015: After receiving feedback that a large part of the files failed to print in Slic3r and Cura, I believe I found an error in the scaling method I used to export the files. All files are updated and check out in 3 slicers I have tested so far. Please report back in case there are still issues.
    Other changes:
  • Added spacers for the bearings as, depending on servo and filament used there is a gap between bearing and turnplate. Print the required thickness and insert it between the bearing mount and the rear top cover
  • updated the rear case to allow the use of a M4 nut for the battery door as the plastic wears out after some time.
  • 2 versions of the rear case are not available. 1 version comes with 4 video connectors and 1 Deans connector, the other with 2 video connectors, one deans and one XT60 connector.
    • 01/03/2015:
  • Added mirror version of the Uno5800 Mount in case you want to install it on the left side or have one Uno5800 on one and a Uno2400 on the other side.
    • 29/03/2015:
  • Corrected Uno2400 mount added (left and right side)
    • 11/04/2015:
  • added modular Antenna mounts. Allows quick change of the following Antenna types:
    1) ImmersionRC 5.8 Patch (IMRC5.8_Lock.stl)
    2) ImmersionRC 2.4 Patch (IMRC2.4_Lock.stl)
    3) Circular Wireless 5.8 Helix (CW5.8_Lock.stl)
    • You will need to replace the tilt head plate with the new lock plate (Head_Lock.stl).

Print with 30% infill except for the pin which should be printed with 100% infill for added strength. Some parts need supports:
  • Case front
  • Cover front
  • Case rear
  • 5800 Mounts (both Duo and the Uno versions)
  • 3DR Case
  • Antenna Plate
    • The case is designed for a Ghettostation Antenna Tracker based on a Arduino Mega 2560 (Teensy is also possible but not used in my design).

    Download the full Ghettostation Code here (check forum below for latest fixes):
    https://github.com/KipK/Ghettostation
    Ghettostation Wiki and setup guide:
    https://github.com/KipK/Ghettostation/wiki
    Ghettostation Forum:
    http://forums.openpilot.org/topic/20823-ghettostation-antenna-tracker-ground-osd/
    Shopping list:
    ===
    Main Tracker:

    1x Mega 2560 R3 ATmega2560-16AU Board plus USB Cable (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__46904__Mega_2560_R3_ATmega2560_16AU_Board_plus_USB_Cable.html)
    1x IIC/I2C/TWI Serial 2004 20x4 LCD Module Shield For Arduino UNO MEGA R3 (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__26852__IIC_I2C_TWI_Serial_2004_20x4_LCD_Module_Shield_For_Arduino_UNO_MEGA_R3.html)
    1x FrSky Battery Voltage Sensor (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__16671__FrSky_Battery_Voltage_Sensor_FrSky_Telemetry_System_.html)
    1x 5V BEC (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__10312__Turnigy_5A_8_26v_SBEC_for_Lipo.html)
    1x Standard Analogue Servo (I used a Hitec HS-325HB) for the tilt head
    1x GWS Digital Servo Sail Winch S125 1T 2BB 360-degree (http://www.goodluckbuy.com/gws-digital-servo-sail-winch-s125-1t-2bb-360-degree-7-6kg-106oz-in-1-28sec.html - I tried the HK analogue type as well but it does not work very well)
    1x Ball Bearing 8x22x7mm (http://shop.rotor.com.sg/show-detail.asp?prodid={0CF678C9-B488-4739-9638-BA12492E7EF7}&pn=1)
    8x Ball Bearing 3x10x4mm (2x http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__11726__HK600GT_Ball_Bearings_Pack_3x10x4mm_4pcs_bag.html)
    3x Push Button (12mm installation diameter)
    1x Piezo Buzzer
    1x 100Ohm Resistor
    4x Video Composite connectors
    1x Deans/T-Style female power connector
    1x Main Power Switch (see case front left side for dimensions)
    1x OSD Power Switch (optional - see case front right side for dimensions)
    1x 6Pin DIN cable to connect the DUO receiver to Video out (Audio modem for telemetry if used)
    3x 43mm Nylon or metal spacers with M3 inside thread

    • M3 socket and sink head screws (I used mostly 8mm and 12mm long types - get a small assortment of different lengths, they always come in handy :-) )
    • min 6x M3 nuts
      ~2 meters of wire to connect all the parts together (I used twisted servo cable for all my connections)
      A number of male and female Servo connectors (or other means to make the connections)
      Telemetry:
    • 3DRobotics Telemetry Set, Clone or your choice of telemetry link (https://store.3drobotics.com/products/3dr-radio)
      Video RX:

      For the VideoRX Part I used (others will work as well but require a different mount on the Tracking Plate):

    • ImmersionRC DUO5800 Receiver (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__38604__ImmersionRC_DUO5800v3_5_8GHz_Diversity_Receiver_w_GS_Link_Dual_Output.html)
    • ImmerosionRC SpiroNet Patch (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__44835__Immersion_Fatshark_SpiroNET_CP_Patch_5_8GHz_Antenna_SMA_13dBi_Gain.html)
    • SMA extension to connect the patch (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__50463__SMA_Male_SMA_Female_180mm_Aerial_Extension_Fatshark_ImmersionRC_Compatible.html)
    • ImmerosionRC SpiroNet Antenna (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__49826__ImmersionRC_5_8GHz_Circular_Polarized_SpiroNet_Antenna_V2_SMA_.html)
    • 7.2V BEC for RX Power supply (7.2V 2.5A UBEC 2-5S Lipoly (6-23v) http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__18787__12V_2_5A_UBEC_2_5S_Lipoly_12_23v_.html)
      Optional:
    • 12V output for FPV goggles - connect to the T-Style Deans connector (12V 2.5A UBEC 2-5S Lipoly (12-23v) http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__18787__12V_2_5A_UBEC_2_5S_Lipoly_12_23v_.html)
    • Ground OSD - minimOSD (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__36844__Minim_OSD_v1_1.html)

comments.text: Sure. Send me a PM with your email and we discuss what you need.
Hi.  I've started printing these parts for my ZMR250, which doesn't have GPS.  Does this work based solely on tracking the video signal or does it require telemetry and/or GPS?  Thanks.
comments.author: CitrusJunkie

comments.text: Yes, you need GPS and a telemetry down link. The Ghettostation SW is not able to track based on receiving side RSSI signal.
comments.author: CitrusJunkie

comments.text: which bearing spacer should I print?
comments.author: skelator

comments.text: Depends on the pan servo and servo arm/disk you use. You can eitger assemble first, measure the gap between bearings and case and print the right spacer afterwards or print all and select the one which gives the best results.
comments.author: skelator

comments.text: using GWS 360 servo, I guess I print the bearing holder first then
comments.author: IdefixRC

comments.text: Yes, you want to install the spacer which allows the bearing to run freely on the case. To thick and they will bind, to loose and the tracking head will be able to swing/wobble

comments.text: What are the 4 big holes under the case for ? What we are supposed to put there ?
comments.author: fantasiiio

comments.text: They are for the feet. Print 4 of them and glue/screw them in place (you can see them in the picture above as well - the black parts). You can add furniture felt pads into the recess on the feet to protect the surface (e.g. car roof) on which you place the tracker. The feet are high enough to still allow the tripod mount adapter to remain in place in the middle of the tracker.

comments.text: I used a 35mm and 8mm spacer together. Alternatively buy 35mm or 40mm nylon spacers (the type with screw holes on both sides) and cut one spacer to the correct length so it comes up to 43mm combined. A longer screw on one side will keep the cut, the full length and one side of the tracker arm in place (I did this with the 2nd one I printed for the EzTracker from ImmersionRC).

comments.author: skelator

comments.text:
In a nutshell: The case has a mount for the pan servo. Simply slot it and and fix it with 4 screws. The bearing ring requires the addition of 8 3x10x4mm ball bearings and is afterwards screwed to the top plate (holes line up). Finally the pan servo disc (supplied with the servo) is screwed to the bottom of the antenna plate. The plate rests on top of the bearing ring and slots into the servo (servo arm/disc mounted to the bottom of the plate). A hole in the middle of the turn assembly allows you to secure the disc with the supplied servo screw to the pan servo.
I will try and add some picture of the 3D rending tomorrow to illustrate the process.

MaakMijnldee's cat figure, see thing:35495, is asymmetric. A mirror reflection turns a right facing cat into a left facing cat that is not superimposable. I find it an attractive motif and suitable for representing the 17 plane groups. Here are 4 coasters for dual extrusion which illustrate plane groups p1, p2, pm and pg. Constructed directly on the build surface they have pleasing smooth surfaces. Four pairs of stl files are provided: cat_coaster_p1.stl and cat_decoration_p1.stl
cat_coaster_p2.stl and cat_deocration_p2.stl
cat_coaster_pm.stl and cat_decoration_pm.stl
cat_coaster_pg.stl and cat_decoration_pg.stl Cat_coasters_01 scad created the stl files and the images are in coasters_dxf_01.zip. Hopefully more will follow.

The coasters are 110 mm in diameter and should be constructed directly on the build surface.   I used one shell and ten percent infill and the coasters printed in about two hours.
The coasters can be used as teaching aids.  The four coasters illustrate  3 of the symmetry elements of the plane groups: reflection lines, glide lines, and 2 fold axes.  Pdf files that show some of the symmetry elements are included in coasters_dxf_01.zip.  Reflection lines are shown in red and glide lines in blue.

title: Quadruped
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It's a quadruped. I haven't tested this, it'd be great if someone would. The servo I used to carve the holes was Tower Pro SG90, but most part of micro servos ought to fit too. (I left  a bit extra space like 1mm or 2)

The files contain an example of the assembled quadruped which is probably self explanatory. On top of the central part there is an arduino uno sketch model for reference. Under the central part there is a breadboard sketch model too. The wires connecting both should go through the hexagon shaped holes. When assembling, the position of the breadboard can be adjusted if you need to place batteries in that zone. (Even if it completely covers 2 hexagon holes, it's ok. They are  there just to keep the wires a little bit more safe). 
There are two different versions of one of the parts of the leg. One is easier to print, but requires you to print that hexagon too and then connect it to the rest with screws.
The servo arms/discs probably should have 4 screws holding them to the parts and then there must be an extra screw to tighten the part+disc  to the servo itself. 
The servos should have screws to mount them on the parts.
I marked this as a work in progress because I haven't tested it, since I haven't a 3D printer.
If you have 3D max, you can open the max file and adjust the size of the central block of one of the servos to meet your needs. All the servos will follow the changes and the same will happen with the holes carved into the parts where servos are supposed to be mounted. Just be careful because if you increase the size a lot, you will need to adjust the parts geometry, or else they will be dijointed.

Works with short inner connector **This is part of a Project i'm doing for uni. The concept is all about re-using old/scrap materials. I've designed a series of connectors that aim to join old scrap pieces into new furniture/homewares.
The idea is that scrap material can be slotted into the inner connector (the diameter of the hole can be changed) and then these connectors slotted into the housing.
The different housings can be used interchangeable to create different objects. The scale of the connectors can also be played with to create new things.

This embroidery design was created fro and donated to the Free Penguin Project (http://www.free-penguin.org/) some years ago. It is designed to fit perfectly their plush tux pattern to provide an easy way to apply eyes to the plush fabric before assembly.

Print the PDF and use the centered crosshairs on the printout to find and mark the desired position on your fabric. 
Color 1 fills and borders the background of the eye, traditionally it uses white thread. Extra underlay is added to prevent show-through on textured dark fabric, as this was originally intended for placement on black, textured material for Tux.
Color 2 fills and borders the iris. Traditionally this is black.
Color 3 is the highlight on the iris. Traditionally, this is white.
The thread colors are not stored in the standard DST file,so the thread choice is, of course, entirely up to the machine operator.

Designed to fit on top of an extendable lamp arm with a 45mm diameter bolt, this allow 3 GU12 LED lamps to replace the old lamp head.  Should work with all sorts of comparable lamp heads, I used this to replace an old strip light head with something more modern.

Print out three of the lamp holders, one lid and one of the two bodies. You might want to flip the lid to print it out the other way up.
Should require just a little cleaning then you should be able to push fit together. I found that the GU12 mounts I used were a tight fit into holders so I didn't glue those but I did glue the holders to the base.
I assembled all the wiring on the holder then attached to the head. On both the lights I have done the wiring comes through the middle of the bolt.
I used computer fan mount screws to attach the lid to the box (I have millions of these). If you don't have any you might want to consider making the mounting holes finer to suit whatever you have.

** This is part of a project i'm doing for uni. The concept is all about re-using old/scrap materials. I've designed a series of connectors that aim to join old scrap pieces into new furniture/homewares.
The idea is that scrap material can be slotted into the inner connector (the diameter of the hole can be changed) and then these connectors slotted into the housing.
The different housings can be used interchangeable to create different objects. The scale of the connectors can also be played with to create new things.

This is a reel for Robox printers. Instead of having third party reel holders on the side of the printer, why not just put your samples or favourite filament to a reel that fits in Robox printer.

'Top' part goes outside, middle facing outside in 'top' part and top (inside part of the reel) at the end. Use appropriate glue to hold them together. I used Silicone Grease (PTFE) on rim of middle part before it was assembled.
I have printed all but current version of the middle. Version I printed I needed to file off excess plastic from inside of the middle bit. Version uploaded has wider curves and I hope it will fit as it is.
Middle part is printed with support and it was quite tricking to be removed from the rim.
NOTE: for ABS plastic don't forget to scale it for 101.7% (102% on Robox)! New: I've just added BottomSmallIn, BottomSmallOut, TopSmallIn and TopSmallOut parts. With middle of the reel you can create reel that is 1/3 width using only BottomSmallIn and TopSmallIn. Also, at that 'core' you can add TopSmallOut (another 1/3 width outer) and BottomSmallOut (another 1/3 outer - other side of the reel). With all four parts you'll get reel divided in three parts - ideal for samples!

comments.text: So it looks like 104% for the rewinder was the magic number.   I now need to reprint your reels at your suggested 102%.
comments.author: Uzbeckin

comments.text:
102% comes from 101.7% that is nominal ABS shrinkage (at least that's what I've gathered).
Your 104% suggests that you'll need to scale your design first (by 2%?) so, when you print it with 102% and ABS it comes to right size. Or, if your design is correct and your prints come 4% smaller - then ABS you're using is shrinking more. Or just design is such that it exaggerates shrinking? (Not sure if that's possible)
comments.author: Uzbeckin

comments.text: You're totally right about needing to go back and adjust it.   I think my ABS is probably the same as most as far as shrinking.  I just wanted to get a working number out there to buy me some time so I can have a working solution while I finish printing giant lego men for all my kids.

I'll work on a nice finishing thumbscrew once I finish the project.   I saw your new reels - nice work as always.

remixed_from.title: Dive Spear for LionFish Hunting 3D Printable

title: Customizable Spear for LIONFISH Fishing / Hunting

description.text:
"Removing 20 lionfish on a single dive equates to saving approximately 300,000 juvenile fish over a one-year period,"said Dr Dayne Buddo of the University of the West Indies' Discovery Bay Marine Lab (UWI-DBML).
Lionfish are the first exotic species to invade coral reefs. They have multiplied at a rate that is almost unheard of in marine history, going from nonexistent to pervasive in just a few short years. Along the way, they've eaten or starved out local fish, disrupted commercial fishing, and threatened the tourism industry. Some experts believe that lionfish are so widespread that their effect on the ecosystems of the Western Atlantic will be almost impossible to reverse. Still, some people are determined to try, if only to protect those waters which haven't yet been invaded.
Download the world's first 3D-printable fully customizable dive spear for lionfish hunting designed by Mold Busters to protect the reefs and the environment. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_I7ceGg3kCU Check out version1 - fully cutomizable dive spear - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49778 For more information about our environmental efforts, please visit https://www.bustmold.com/locations/ottawa/ or https://www.bustmold.com/locations/montreal/
It can be customized by many parameters. Check it out - It's really cool!

title: GoPro Frame for the Hero 4 Silver

description.text:
This is a simple remix of the GoPro Frame:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:507061 by GoPro_3d.
A few change have been made to fit perfectly the 4 Silver, some minor issues bother me enough to adapt the well designed frame to make it perfect:

  • Cut out on the lower left backside to reach the LCD button easily
  • Unblock the Mic on the top near the REC button
  • Cut out on the bottom side for the build in speaker
    The "OPENED" version have the lower portion between the braquet not connected in cas the standard version does not hold the GoPro strong enough.
    Of course the Frame does hold the GoPro 3, 3+ and 4 in all there variant without issues.

    Ceci est un remix de la Frame Gopro:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:507061 par Gopro_3d.
    Quelques changement ont été apporté pour l'adapter à la GoPro 4 Silver, certaines petites choses étaient gênante, suffisament pour que je l'adapte pour la rendre parfaite:

  • Découpe sur le bas gauche à l'arrière pour atteindre le bouton LCD facilement.
  • Débloquer le micro sur le dessus à coté du bouton REC.
  • Découpe sur le dessous pour le haut parleur intégré.
    La version "OPENED" a le bas entre les pattes non connecté au cas ou la version standard ne tiens pas bien la GoPro.
    Bien sur la Frame supporte les GoPro 3, 3+ et 4 dans toute leur variante sans problème.
Some model are not there, you can find more here: https://www.cgtrader.com/M600

title: Maker Gear M2 Dial Indicator Mount and Indicator Point

description.text: For simplified bed leveling and Z-stop indication just behind the nozzle.  An update of the r2 extruder motor mount with gussets added for strength and a post (10 mm) for mounting a standard dial indicator with a standard post clamp.  The printed dial indicator point can be installed between any standard indicator point and the indicator shaft.  The bed leveling and Z-stop setup is quick and I have been adjusting the Z stop to -.005 in to get good prints.

Both components were printed with PLA using Simplify 3D with the fine setting, 80% fill and auto generate supports on.  The indicator point was printed upright with manual supports added all along the spine (looks like a harp) and used the hex wrenches (2 mm and 4 mm) provided with the M2 to ream the indicator attachment holes then sanded the point and support areas smooth.  The extruder mount was printed with the cable caddy pointing up and required removal of the auto-generated supports in the holes (difficult but doable) and along the front of the post.  The post on the extruder mount required some sanding to smooth it out

title: LED Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I wanted to shed a little more light onto my printbed so that I could see what was going on better and time lapses would be clearer through Octoprint.
It will work just fine without the cover piece, but I wanted the cover to hide the wires and LED leads.
I have mine setup with 2 3.3v clear LEDs connected to a 2xAA battery pack with a switch ( planning on connecting them to the GPIO of the Raspberry Pi running Octoprint soon )
Depending on how well calibrated your printer is you may have to drill out the LED holes slightly.
The ridges on the inside of the cover piece are not clips, they're meant to be stops so that the cover doesn't get pressed too far over the LED holder. Mine friction fit together but I added a little hot glue to secure the cover in place. it friction fit onto the printer very well and doesn't seem to move at all during a print

title: shapeoko 2 end stop / limit switch holder (X and Y Axis)

description.text:
This is an adjustable endstop that hold a common SPDT type limit switch available at places like Radio Shack in the US.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cqKog4fOuMl

You'll need two M5 or similar bolts and channel t-nuts
https://www.inventables.com/technologies/post-assembly-insertion-nuts
I chose to use two for stability. You can probably get away with one. There is a groove in the design for screws to fit in to that was made specifically for the switches I had
https://www.evernote.com/shard/s283/sh/131779e7-2a6f-45b8-8a7a-24ac768e3e8b/ba01d6baf33095059aa76ff222d40fe1
I used metal screws that were small enough to fit in to the switch and it worked great.

title: Power Supply Bracket for Mounting an enclosed power supply

description.text:
Power supply mounting bracket for enclosed power supply like thise
https://www.inventables.com/technologies/enclosed-power-supply
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/4HzvFy6ki4m

Print out a bracket, snap your enclosed power supply in to place and drill holes into the bracket for mounting to your workspace or enclosure. Y0u can optionally add a zip tie through the tie points on the top of hte bracket. I printed mine with 2 shells, 10% infill and 300 micron layer height and it was rigid and still flexible enough to insert and remove the power supply.
You'll probably need to print with supports to get the small overhang and tie down holes, Mine were difficult to remove.

author: byllc

title: E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage mount Prusa i3

description.text:
Version 2 released: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847 If you have a Prusa i3 and are upgrading your hotend to an E3D v6 with Bowden, then you'll need this hotend mount for your X-carriage. As this design clamps the hotend to the mount, there's no chance of a wobbly hotend. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSiWot9tib8 NOTE: Added dual fan mounts with fan duct
21 May 15 - Added 'clone' carriage and clamp for non-genuine E3D hotend
28 Jun 15 - Added carriage clamp with side blow fan mount

2 Parts - The carriage and the clamp.
Print both at 0.2mm with 30% infill. To clamp this unit together, you'll need 2 x M4 screws with 20mm length and 2 x M4 nuts.

Fan option added:
You can now attach a 50mm fan on either/both sides of the carriage clamp.
Side Blow Fans also ;)

second_letter = Y
A 3D Printed Case for mounting the Beagle Bone to the TurtleBot.

This is a 3D Printable Case designed for the Beagle Bone printed on a Replicator Dual.
Additional Items Needed:
4 M4 Heated Threaded Inserts: http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180A351
4 M4 Thumb Screws: http://www.mcmaster.com/#92581A230
2 M3 Heated Threaded Inserts: http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180A331
2 4mm M3 Screws: http://www.mcmaster.com/#91292A109
1 8" Velcro Strap: http://www.mcmaster.com/#6605K52 There are TWO (2) sets of files included. One set for printing a case that houses only the Beagle Bone. One set for printing a case that can house user installed shield and wiring.

  • The Smaller Beagle Bone Case can be printed with the default Replicator settings. The Big Beagle Bone Case is a large object and as such subject to curling. It is recommend you use preventative techniques such as enclosing the printer or adjusting the print speed of the first few layers as suggested here: http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/06/21/going-slow/ .

  • Once printed, use the proper heating tool (like a compatible soldering iron tip) to install (2) M3 threaded inserts in the holes located inside the bottom half of the case. Install (4) M4 threaded inserts in the holes underneath the bottom half of the case.

  • Place Velcro strap through the ports on the sides of the case.

  • Fasten the Beagle Bone inside the Bottom Half using (2) 4mm M3 screws.

  • Place top cover into position and secure case with velcro.

  • Fasten to TurtleBot using (4) M4 Thumb Screws

description.text:
Hi,
here's a brand new electronic game for my daughter inspired by the famous game Etch-A-Sketch.
the left potentiometer controls vertical pitch
the right potentiometer controls horizontal pitch
the red button clears the screen.
Parts list:
1 arduino nano
2 linear potentiometers 100k
1 push button
1 little switch
1 lcd screen type nokia 5510
4 AAA batteries.
All these parts were found on Ebay.
Salut,
Voici un nouveau jeu électronique pour ma fille inspiré par le célèbre jeu Télécran .
le potentiomètre gauche contrôle la hauteur verticale
le potentiomètre droit contrôle la hauteur horizontale
le bouton rouge efface l'écran .
Liste des pièces :
1 Arduino Nano
2 potentiomètres linéaires 100k
1 bouton -poussoir
1 petit interrupteur
1 LCD type nokia 5510
4 piles AAA .
Toutes ces pièces ont été trouvées sur Ebay .

Follow the schematics to wire your etch-a-rduino...
Suivez le schéma pour cabler votre Télécrarduino... You have to download these librairies in order to use the nokia 5510 screen:
Vous devez telecharger les librairies suivantes pour utiliser l'écran du nokia 5510 -Adafruit_GFX.h https://github.com/adafruit/Adafruit-GFX-Library
-Adafruit_PCD8544.h https://github.com/adafruit/Adafruit-PCD8544-Nokia-5110-LCD-library Here's the code: (remove "" on the 4 first lines)
Voila le code: (enlevez "" sur les 4 premières lignes) "" #include ""<""Adafruit_GFX.h"">
"" #include ""<""Adafruit_PCD8544.h"">
"" #define vertical A1
"" #define horizontal A0
// pin 8 - Serial clock out (SCLK)
// pin 9 - Serial data out (DIN)
// pin 10 - Data/Command select (D/C)
// pin 11 - LCD chip select (CS)
// pin 12 - LCD reset (RST)
Adafruit_PCD8544 display = Adafruit_PCD8544(8, 9, 10, 11, 12);
int valeurX =0;
int valeurY =0;
void setup() {
pinMode(vertical, INPUT);
pinMode(horizontal, INPUT);
pinMode(2, INPUT_PULLUP);
display.begin();
display.setContrast(50);
display.clearDisplay();
}
void loop() { valeurX = analogRead(horizontal) / 12.3;
valeurY = analogRead(vertical) / 21.7;
display.setContrast(60);
display.drawPixel(valeurX, valeurY, BLACK);
display.display();
if (digitalRead(2)==LOW){display.clearDisplay();} }

title: ball mount for a small mirror

description.text: This is a ball mount for a small mirror which allows rotation about any axis. The mirror rim is 52.5 mm diameter by 4.88 mm thick.

Glue (with acetone) the ball_141114b.stl to mirror_mount_141113b.stl. Glue clip_141114g.stl to mount_141115.stl. snap the ball into clip_141114g.stl. Use double stick foam tape to attach to top of monitor. Some of the design concepts:
The ball diameter is 20 mm.
The 3 arms have 20 mm ball diameter indents. However the arms have been moved inward 0.5 mm to provide a slight preload on the ball to keep in place. The preload will be sensitive to the arm length and inward movement of the three arms in clip_141114g.stl. A higher preload will hold the mirror in place more tightly. Shorter arms increase the ball preload because they will be stiffer (proportional to L^3). Moving the arm radially inward more also increases the preload. The limit to these two effects is that the arms will break when inserting the ball. If you use the design concept for other applications, please share with the community.

author: tc_fea

description.text: Bracket to hold Maxon 137506 gearmotor (36 volt, 5 watt, 152 rpm) including a model of the motor itself. OpenSCAD file provided for modifications (maybe front face should be thicker?) Useful over a range of voltages: for example 15 rpm at 3.54 V (unloaded), and it keeps turning down to 0.2 volts (2 mA). The DC winding resistance is 60 ohms. It works as a generator also. It is not completely quiet, but it is less noisy than cheaper gearmotors. This one is available at some surplus stores.
The motor face takes 3x M2 screws, and the bracket bottom has holes for 4x M3 screws.

title: Organizer for DeWalt 17 piece SAE tap/die set

description.text: This tap and die set from Home Depot is good, but comes in a throwaway plastic shell and the bits are not labeled with the corresponding tap. This organizer keeps them stored compactly, even with a little slot for the piece of the back packaging that says which bit goes with which tap.

Printed at "low" quality with raft on 2X with 3rd-party filament.
Design notes:
I measured all of the pieces with calipers and added a .02" diameter tolerance. This was perfect for the large tools (dies and drivers) but the bits and taps have a very tight fit. Actual uploaded model has the bits and taps with an additional .02" on top of that, in case anyone prints it. Also spaced out the bits a little since it's hard to take out one of the middle ones. Should have thought about the angle of the tap driver, since it increases the profile at any angle it's inserted. Lofted bottom of that worked great.
Card slot was an experimental afterthought but worked great.

description.text:
EDIT: Better version here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090368 by TheLongRunSmoke! Why use a plain old dice when you can have an awesome dedicated turn counter! I made this to work for Warhammer 40K, so the max number of turns is 7 and there is a day/night marker.
Its intended to be assembled with glue once painted. The wheels should snap on each number because of the little clicker arm thingies (no idea what they're actually called in engineering). You might need to sand down some parts (especially the clickers) for it to turn smoothly. EDIT- Final version! (at least for now). Printed the WIP version and didn't like it too much. I thought it could work fine without a bottom cap but I was wrong, so this new version has one, as well as better dimensions on the clicky things and the wheels so the clicks are solid and satisfying. Also; minor cosmetic changes on the handles. It still need to be assembled with glue and will still probably require a little sanding (especially on the top cap) but overall, I'm happy with how it looks and work for now.

comments.text: "Little clicker thingies" are called "detents".  Just thought you might like to know!
comments.author: industriald

comments.text: Thanks! Learned it since then but I appreciate you taking the time to share that.
comments.author: industriald

comments.text: Thanks for this model. I really enjoyed printing and making it. I didn't sand the top, but I feel it gives it a sort of brushed metal look that fits warhammer and 40k.
comments.author: Jearil

comments.text: Glad it worked well for you! Tolerances were made for my specific printer so I was wondering how well it would assemble if printed on a different machine. Paint looks great!
comments.author: Jearil

comments.text: Thanks! It turned out pretty well. The only issue I ended up having is that the click wheel gets stuck at times (I should have sanded it before assembly) and because I did a medium fill on the parts, the handle took too much torque and snapped off when I was turning it. I ended up setting a brass rod inside and gluing it together again. I mainly try to just be gentle when turning it now. I may try making another with the handle being solid though.

author: Morphiapp

description.text:
A perfect gift for children or teachers. Add your own name/text.
.
Requires Brim for a successful print. The 4 small center pillars are designed for support.

This is a derivative of the collegeBot that was modified to use a dual motor gearbox, a speaker with a larger magnet, a push button with a larger diameter and slightly smaller slide switch.
The changes only required some minor modifications to the openscad files. Thanks to the collegebot creator for publishing scad files and not just the stls!
The side panels and the head remain unchanged from the original collegebot. The major change to the design was that the bot had to be made narrower due to the fact that the two gearboxes can't be mounted separately. Thus the top, speaker shelf and bottom plate had to made narrower.
The bottom plate was also changed into a single piece since it would fit my build area.
These are the revised parts:
Gearbox:
http://www.pololu.com/product/61
Pushbutton:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00D7C443C
Speaker:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008999NS
Slideswitch:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007Q9YCAC
I also am using a full size arduino instead of a nano and mounting it on the bottom.
Note: the build is not fully complete at this point. The printed parts all seem to work. Just the wiring remains to be done.
Also haven't decided on exact battery arrangement to use, but leaning towards a 6 AA battery arrangement to supply both the arduino and the motor supply, tapping for the lower motor voltage.

author: Petitbrochet

description.text:
Hex tiles!  GURPS players rejoice!
After I made the Mountain Game board demo I decided to do something for the more formal gamers out there.  These hex tiles interlock, so that each nine-hex building block can be hooked in a fairly sturdy fashion to the others, forming an arbitrary-size game board for pretty much pocket change.
In addition to standard hex slabs (what would be the fun of something you could do with paper, right?), the 3D print aspect of the hex tiles lets them be extruded to create arbitrary height fields (demoed in the hill pieces, but extensible to just about ANYTHING) and the wall pieces included can be used to build arbitrary structures.
And naturally, this is only the beginning!  With the implemented "software standard hex" shapes, figurine bases, stackable landscape add-ons, and virtually anything you can extrude out of or union onto the base plates can become part of the game pieces.
Game on!
I've taken the commercial restriction off this one for a reason-- I want to see people SELLING these, and if all I get is my name on the box, I'll be a happy camper!

remixed_from.author: mike_mattala
remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text: Our floor isn't level, which means our table isn't level, which means our printer isn't level. It's close, but even with assisted leveling of the build platform our prints had regular curling and peeling, raft or not. I modified this Thing and made some nuts and bolts from this Thing and was able to make adjustable feet for my printer. After leveling the printer itself, and then doing assisted leveling for the platform, our prints are now pristine works of uncurled PLA mastery.

For each foot, print the following:
  • 1 bottom
  • 1 top
  • 1 bolt
  • 2 nuts
    • I recommend that you print the nuts and bolts separate from the tops and bottoms. The tops and bottoms can be done at 0.2mm layer height, 2 shells, and 10% infill. The nuts and bolts are the load-bearing pieces, so they should be stronger. I changed infill to 25%, and that seems sufficient. Assemble each foot as follows:
  • Slide a bolt through the bottom so the hex head is flush in its receiver. The bottom piece is the shorter of the two.
  • Screw a nut down over the bolt to hold it in place. This step is optional, but I felt better with the bolt being securely attached to the bottom piece for load distribution.
  • Screw another nut down over the bolt. Make sure that this nut does not touch the first nut or else you might unscrew both nuts when adjusting.
  • Drop the top piece over the top nut so that the nut is inside of its receptacle. Adjust the height so that the tip of the bolt is just beneath the top of the assembled foot.
  • Repeat with the other three feet.
  • Gently place the feet under the corners of your printer.
  • Place a level on the printer floor, not on the build platform. Adjust the feet until you have the bubble centered from left to right and front to back. You can (and should) adjust the feet without removing them from under the printer.
  • Once you have the printer leveled, continue with assisted leveling.
    • Let me know if your print quality improves!

comments.text:
Just what I was looking for, perfect build no problems. Considering I built all four items at the same time the only problem I had was the #2 extruder nozzle "bumping" into some objects. I had to re-adjust the platform "on the fly" but it worked. Next set I'll build all of one kind at the same time to avoid that problem.
May I suggest gluing some cork (or something) to the bottom of the "foot" to keep the machine from "walking" and it dampens some noise.
Thanks again,
Don

description.text: The comments in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106568 mention a few problems with that version, and I had similar problems when I printed one, so I imported it into openscad (you'll need to download those original files to use the openscad source included with this thing) and produced this new version. Uses 1.75mm filament as the pin instead of printing one. Adds some ribs to the area that clamps the paper to hold it better. Removes a feathered edge at the bottom that was too thin to print well.

Print the 3 stl files. Use a small drill bit to enlarge the holes if necessary so 1.75mm filament will fit through them. Glue a length of 1.75mm filament to each washer, run the other end of the filament through the holes in the platen and the stands and glue the other end of the filament to the stand so the platen can rotate freely, but is held in place side to side.  
Now you can run the paper between the stand and the platen and clip the platen down to hold the paper in place. The small ribs on the platen and stand will grab the paper so it won't slide around.

description.text: We stretched the Makies Cowboy Boots in order to give them a "Pirate" Look.

Simple feet for the Simple Metal.  I've included both the whole model and the model split as bottom and top - try printing the bottom part in flex material, then overprint the top part in ABS by swapping out to the ABS filament, loading the top gcode in, then printing again w/o removing the bottom parts.  The top STL is tricked-out by adding an unprintable block to make the model "float" at the correct level (on top of the bottom) when loaded into Cura.  
Also included the .stl file to make it easier to edit in Sketchup (8).

I find printing the flex filament slowly (5mm/s) works best, and you may want to slow down the ABS print as well (10mm/s), to make it stick better to the flex - note that the ABS will not have a "first" layer, so setting for that will be irrelevant.

comments.text: Thanks for the tip, Gordon.  I reprinted the feet using the Simple Slow profile and got better results.  I will certainly try the 85% extrusion rate for future parts that need better dimensional accuracy.  Thanks for the tip!

description.text:
This is a mount for a GoPro or SJ4000 action camera to reduce vibration while recording video or transmitting FPV video. It is designed to attach to the bottom or top plate of your Spyda 500 quadcopter. The mount was designed by combining Gyrobot's existing mount and the DEEJAYEYE solid plate. Note, the holes don't align to the crossfire hole pattern.
One plate is secured to the body, while the other is attached to the first plate using 3 rubber o-rings. The 2 plates sandwich 5 foam earplugs to provide the dampening effect.

title: CRONIOS the LED Clock (WS2812 Strip = 60 pieces) laser cut

description.text:
http://www.led-genial.de/CRONIOS-die-tolle-Dekouhr-aus-LED-Lich http://www.led-genial.de/CRONIOS-Elektronik-Platine-fuer-Selberbauer CRONIOS's heart is a modern 32 bit cortex controller with an integrated real time clock and an integrated USB interface. The battery life is approximately 10 years and it can be replaced if depleted. CRONIOS can also be connected to a PC so there are numerous ways for personalization and configuration. Setting the clock to daylight saving time (DST) is no problem for CRONIOS because it switches those automatically. A PC-based configuration program is included as well. Several parameters like color, brightness, and the duration of effects can be adjusted. Simply attach CRONIOS to your PC and configure it according to your personal preferences.
CRONIOS is a designing experiment.
CRONIOS uses bright state-of-the-art digital RGB LEDs. Everyone of the 60 LEDs comes with its own digital PWM controller. Hence, every single LED can have a distinct color and brightness. Its power is provided via the USB interface. In addition, it can also be used to configure the color profile.
CRONIOS can also be configured in a more direct fashion: a rotary disk recognizes that you want to change CRONIOS’s appearance—you could try a new color profile or simply set the timer when you cook an egg.

for assembly see my video
http://youtu.be/apOieefTUc8

description.text:

Due to the position of the Bowden extruder and the filament spool on my Prusa i3 the filament need to turn 180deg. I prepared a slim box including a 25cm tube (inner diameter 2mm). It's mounted on top of Z holder using the existing skews.

It's designed for 3mm birch plywood. In order to avoid soot you can protect a side of the plywood with paper tape. Cut and engrave in one step and remove the tape when finished. Plug together with or without glue (it's fitting tight). Good luck.

I was pretty concerned about people telling that their endstop fails crashing hardly the extruder into the glass-plate with a very seriously risk of being broken.
So before to experience such a bad situation I worked on an easily piece wich prevents that kind of situation.

Instructions are simple: -Print the file
-Remove the back pannel
-Unscrew one z spindle bolt and pass it through the first hardstopper base hole and mid tight it
-Do the same with the second and secure it firmly P.S: I printed mine at 0'3mm per layer, this piece doesnÃÂ´t need a big resolution.

description.text:
Fly somewhere cool and take a picture! The Escape i Tri Pod is a tripod for your phone and a spaceship. This thing came out of a challenge at MakerBot headquarters during the Make-a-thon. The instructions were that the thing had to be a wow worthy quick print that is useful, bonus for moving parts. I'm not sure if the Escape i Tripod accomplishes any of those instruction guidelines, but it was fun!  
I would encourage some tweaking between the slider rails and the holes that they slide through. I used a .2mm difference because that's the tolerance that works on our machine at home, but it was waaaaay too tight on the finely tuned machines at MakerBot HQ.

title: SHOP VACUUM HOSE SWIVEL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Swivel adapter for 2 1/2" shop vacuum hose. Keeps hose from twisting up as you move about your shop. Can be installed between vacuum
and hose or hose and hand tool.

Print out parts. No support is required. Extension was required to
keep the swivel from binding on vacuum canister when used
between vac and hose. Extension is not required if used at the tool end of the hose. You will need (33) 1/4" diameter steel or plastic ball bearings and (8) #4 x 1/2" sheet metal screws. Load the bearings
between the inner and outer swivel parts (apply light grease if
desired) and clamp in place with the ring and screws. I noticed very
little if any vacuum leakage in use. I have included a STEP file and DXF cross sectional view for those with the ability and desire to
modify the design for their own application.

title: Morphi Mini Taj Mahal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Mini model of the Taj Mahal made in Morphi app. This was one of our first test models made in the app and we've included it for instructive purposes. It's a minimalist model and still a work in progress. If you chose to print this model, please read the instructions prior to printing. In Morphi, users of all skill levels can make 3D printable objects on the go using touch, without wifi or a mouse. www.morphiapp.com Download the app for free for iPad and IPad mini on the App Store. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android! Copyright 2014-2015, The Inventery, Inc.

This was one of the earliest experimental/test models made in Morphi. www.morphiapp.com. We designed it in a minimalist style using ellipsoids, cubes, cylinders and spheres. Please note that this model is still a work in progress - a quick rendering/sketch made as we were still revising alignment and other tools in the app. The model is included in the app for instructive purposes. If you decide to print this model, below are a few important notes and suggestions for you to read prior to printing: -The thin platform underneath the bottom of the Taj Mahal needs support in order for it to touch the build plate. You can generate this in your slicing software and it will supplement the existing platform so that it touches the build plate. In Cura, for example, simply check the Print Support Structure box. -We designed this test model in a large size so you may want to scale it down prior to print by at least 40%. If you don't do this, it will take a very long time to print - even on the quickest settings. -You may want to slow down the printer speed by 50% overall when printing and especially when printing the smaller domes and their supporting structures. Print our model or make your own in Morphi. Download the app for free in iTunes. https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/morphi/id833530351?mt=8 Coming soon for Android!

Dogbone tabs fit together to hold piece in place, keyhole adapters are if you dont want to screw it on the wall.

I was looking up some gear mechanisms and stumbled upon this fantastic spinning top that looks like Mt Fuji when you twirl it. This is something I did using the same principles, as you spin it, you see a volcanic cone with a mist around it. Mine's a lot flatter and wider, so I'll call it Mt Ruapehu (Auckland, New Zealand). I reccomend printing this with very different coloured filaments. I only had grey and white and it could really use more contrast. Try black/white or dark blue/white. I've attached 2 STLs. They should be all set up. You will need rafts, but it printed fine without supports.

Print the wedge with the stick at the bottom and wedge on the top with a raft. You should not need supports  
Print the spinner with the wedge-shaped hole at the bottom on a raft. Shouldn't need supports for this either.

^^  
Good luck

description.text: Glider with a futuristic-looking outline, prints in one step

Print with 100% fill, I used PLA with 0.2mm first layer, 0.1mm layers for the rest.
You'll probably need to bend up the tail a little to get it trimmed and bend up the wings to get some dihedral (for roll stability) - see the photos for what I mean, try to keep it symmetrical!
It's quite hard to throw; I find the best way is to hold either side of the fuselage forward of the wing root - try not to twist when you throw! There are now two versions of the STL, one with a 0.4mm thick fin and one with 0.8mm thickness - see edit 2 for details. If your slicer program doesn't like the single-pass fin at 0.4mm try 0.8 or re-generate the STL from the scad file with whatever thickness you want to try. The whole model is formed from extruded DXFs in OpenSCAD so you can alter them in Inkscape if you want (SVG sources provided - but OpenSCAD won't work with curves in DXFs so convert to lines with 'Extensions > Modify Path > Flatten Beziers' first then re-export to DXF)
edit The fin is a single-wall part which went a bit funny when I recently printed it on a RepRap with a big print fan blowing on it, it seemed to blow the printing layer off the previous one - it doesn't seem to be a problem for all printers (fine on my mini kossel and on one of the prints here) but I'll see if I can find a way to make a version that might be better. I also added in a missing DXF file.
edit 2 The fin seems to be causing problems on some printers/slicers, I haven't got easy access to anything except Slic3r/mini kossel to test on at the moment (& this is fine with the thin fin) so I've uploaded a couple of new STLs, one with a 0.4mm fin thickness and one with 0.8mm to see if that helps. I've also changed the .scad file to allow the fin thickness to be changed more easily if you want to.
edit 3 Changed the *.scad file to use the layers in the DXF file (always there just didn't realise OpenScad could use them) and included the SVG source. As suggested by dgatza I also edited the DXF to round out the back of the nose for strength as a couple of people have found it broke on a heavy landing.

comments.text: how do you actually throw it? i'm perplex
comments.author: meekaah

comments.text:
I found that the best way is to hold in front of the wing and try to throw straight as you can, avoiding any twisting as you release as the lateral stability isn't that great. Dihedral (bending up the wings at the wing roots so that the tips are higher) helps a bit with lateral stability and the tails need to be bent up a the trailing edges for longitudinal stability and the right attitude.
You're right that it isn't the easiest plane to throw though, I compromised performance a bit there for a couple of reasons: to make it look swishy and print in one piece with about the right balance (which amongst other things made it wide at the front and back) and to make the front blunt enough that it would be less likely to hurt people (although you shouldn't throw toward people if possible anyway). I did have plans for a couple more designs but I have a very, very big project on the go (so far 3h + 6h printing and less than halfway there) so I haven't been able to test & upload yet.
Hope that helps, I found practice improved my throw (although my first go was a lucky one :)

Surprisingly the vertical stabilizer survived repeated test flights.  Figured that'd be the first thing to bust off.  Might give it another try at 1:1 scale using a different slicer.

comments.text:

In general the aircraft is a little nose heavy if you don't bend the horizontal tail up a bit (the photos show this a little on my print, not very well though) - this isn't ideal but it will tend to make the aircraft a little more stable in flight. A thicker fin might change this balance but probably not that much.

I've been following the ESA's Rosetta spacecraft for a while now and just thought it would be nice to have a little model. Unfortunately, the only one I could fine is off of the NASA website. Not very printer friendly and as one file, It wouldn't have scaled up properly. I'm slowly working on making it a three piece model. First the solar panels and then the main body. There might be a few other parts that will have to be printed on there own, so we'll see where we end up. Full Rosetta spacecraft is from http://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/detail/eoss-rosetta Smaller, more manageable pieces will follow. Purple solar panel was a test.

title: Bat Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I always wondered how Batman's suit was returned from the cleaners. It turns out it comes back on a Bat-Hanger. This little guy was my first design using my new LASER cutter. It works well to prevent pointed shoulders from cheap hangers, and also can be used to hold Batgirls special clothing. The curves allow for straps to be set in place with no worry of them sliding off while in storage. I tried to make the hook part resemble the "?" of the Riddler. Though the size is a little small due to the limited cutting space, it can easily be scaled up to accommodate larger clothing (assuming your cutter has the room to cut it).

title: Corvo Mask for Small Print Beds

description.text: I loved the corvo designs that had been uploaded, but none of them were load and print ready, especially not on a 100X100 printbed of a printerbot.  This design has been seperated into six parts and scaled to fit an average face.  Recomendations for further modifications: carving out the inside of the shape to fit closer to ones face.

The top parts need to be glued together unfortunately, but if done carefully it still looks good.  Two thickneses of garden wire were used to put the left, right, and jaw peices together.  Holes were made with heated nails, just big enough to pass the wire through.
